title: Musicr
tagline: Real-time chat where every message maps to a song
summary: Anonymous real-time chat where each message is matched to a song using semantic similarity. Type anything — a mood, a memory, a joke — and Musicr finds the closest track from a 114k-song catalog using pgvector HNSW cosine search. No accounts, no sign-up.
imageAlt: Chat bubbles and sound wave representing Musicr

status.label: Live — seeking feedback
status.note: Deployed on Railway. Collecting early user feedback on matching quality and UX.

sections.title: How it works
items: User types any message — a mood, a memory, an observation — in the anonymous chat.
The server embeds the text with Xenova/all-MiniLM-L6-v2 (384-dim, runs server-side, no external API needed).
pgvector performs HNSW cosine similarity search across a 114k-song catalog (title, artist, tags, album metadata).
The matched song appears in the chat instantly. Click it to listen on YouTube.
Threaded replies let users react and riff on each match.

sections.title: Stack
items: API: Fastify + WebSocket, per-IP rate limiting, maintenance mode, hard 500-char input cap.
DB: PostgreSQL + pgvector — HNSW index on 384-dim embedding vectors, cosine distance operator (<=>).
Embeddings: Xenova/all-MiniLM-L6-v2 local model — no OpenAI dependency in production.
Frontend: React 18 + Zustand + Tailwind CSS + Vite.
Monorepo: pnpm workspaces (apps/api, apps/web, shared/types).
Deployment: Railway — API via Dockerfile, web via Nixpacks, PostgreSQL addon with pgvector.

sections.title: Design decisions
items: Fully anonymous — users get a hashed-IP handle; no PII stored.
Matching uses song metadata only (no lyrics), so results are sometimes uncanny and sometimes a stretch — that tension is intentional.
Catalog seeded with diversity caps per artist to ensure breadth across 114k tracks.
Launched on Show HN with security hardening: Gitleaks CI, Dependabot, secret rotation runbook.

title: AI Agent Firewall
tagline: Policy-driven guardrails for AI agent actions
summary: Prototype firewall that gates AI agent communications against a versioned, human-reviewed policy set. Extracts rule candidates from PDF policy documents via LLM, routes them through a human review step, then deterministically evaluates outgoing messages with an explainable trace.
imageAlt: Shield and policy rule cards representing an AI agent firewall

status.label: Early prototype
status.note: Core evaluation engine and policy versioning complete. UI refinement in progress.

sections.title: What it does
items: Upload a policy PDF (e.g., an insurance contract) and extract rule candidates via the Anthropic API.
Human reviewers approve, reject, or edit candidates before rules become active.
Rules are versioned — each policy set is immutable; edits produce a new version via clone-and-edit.
The evaluation engine deterministically checks outgoing agent messages against the active policy and returns a pass/fail trace with per-rule explanations.
Magic-link auth with RBAC (admin, test_user, demo) — no passwords.

sections.title: Rule templates
items: FORBIDDEN_PHRASE — blocks/escalates messages containing prohibited language.
REQUIRED_DISCLOSURE — enforces presence of mandated disclosures based on message conditions.
REQUIRE_REASON_CODE — requires valid reason codes on denial decisions.
REQUIRE_CITATION — ensures policy or regulatory citations accompany claims.
CHANNEL_RESTRICTION — limits which communication channels may be used.

sections.title: Stack
items: Next.js 15 App Router — server and client components.
Prisma ORM + PostgreSQL — versioned policy storage and evaluation logs.
Anthropic API (@anthropic-ai/sdk) — LLM-assisted rule candidate extraction from PDFs.
pdf-parse — server-side PDF text extraction.
Railway — deployment target with volume-mounted PDF storage.

title: Wealth Distribution Viz
tagline: Interactive explorer for global wealth distribution data
summary: Single-page visualization of global wealth distribution using UBS Global Wealth Report 2023 data. Define custom wealth brackets and explore how 3.77 billion adults are distributed from $0 to $100B+. 76 fine-grained bins combining real survey data with Pareto-modeled ultra-high-wealth ranges.
imageAlt: Bar chart of global wealth distribution by bracket

status.label: Stable
status.note: Live and stable. Future work: regional breakdowns and historical time-series.

sections.title: Features
items: Define custom wealth brackets and see how the global population distributes across them in real time.
Toggle between percentage-of-population and absolute headcount views.
Coverage analytics show what share of global wealth and population your brackets capture.
76 data bins from $0 to $100B+: real UBS data, linear interpolation, and Pareto-modeled ultra-high-wealth tail (α = 1.3–1.5).
No build step, no backend — pure HTML, CSS, and JavaScript with Chart.js via CDN. Just open and run.

sections.title: Data methodology
items: Source: UBS Global Wealth Report 2023 (2022 data) — $454.4T total wealth, 3.77B adults tracked.
Original data provides 4 coarse bins; fine-grained bins derived via linear interpolation ($0–$1M) and Pareto distribution modeling ($1M+).
All bins normalized to sum to exact global totals for mathematical consistency.
Data quality clearly labelled per bin: real, interpolated, or modeled.

title: Protein Explorer
tagline: Residue proximity explorer for PDB structures
summary: Lightweight browser viewer that cycles through random Protein Data Bank structures with live metadata, residue proximity maps, and interaction analysis.
heroAlt: Screenshot of the Protein Explorer slideshow highlighting metadata panel

status.label: On hold
status.note: Paused while focusing on current projects.

sections.title: Key features
items: Random slideshow of 15 Protein Data Bank entries refreshed automatically for quick exploration.
Resilient structure loading that falls back across gzipped CIF, raw CIF, and PDB formats to avoid API hiccups.
Metadata side panel with experiment method, resolution, chains, symmetry, annotations, and primary literature links.
Representation controls (Cartoon, Surface, Ball & Stick) plus quick residue load for focused inspection.
Proximity threshold slider that rehydrates the contact map and highlights residues within 1–5 Å.
Interaction-aware highlighting that distinguishes reachable residues from predicted chemical interactions.

sections.title: Controls & UI
items: Keyboard shortcuts for play/pause and stepping through structures (Space, ←, →).
Toolbar actions for toggling spin, changing representations, and loading specific PDB IDs.
Quick-load inputs for jumping directly to residue labels such as ALA A265.
Side-chain interaction analyzer supporting 2–10 residue selections with hydrogen bond and salt bridge detection.
Filter neighbors toggle to reduce the residue list to active contacts when desired.
Responsive layout tuned for centered stage presentation on desktop and mobile.

title: Runway FOD Detection
tagline: Computer vision pipeline for foreign object debris alerts
summary: Detection stack that pairs YOLO with RCNN persistence tracking so airside teams can triage debris before it becomes costly FOD.
imageAlt: Magnifying glass revealing runway debris alerts

status.label: On hold
status.note: Concept work paused. See Pathreader for active aviation safety work.

sections.title: Problem statement
body: Detect objects in the field of view and classify them as cleared (no impact to operations) or not cleared (threat to operations). Prioritize detections by size, material, and proximity to active runways.

sections.title: Approach
items: Collect day/night runway imagery with bounding boxes and threat labels.
Train YOLOv8 / Faster R-CNN models with calibrated confidence thresholds.
Fuse detections across frames to estimate persistence and reduce false positives.
Provide operator UX with explainable metadata—size, distance, sample frames—for rapid triage.

sections.title: Implementation notes
items: Edge deployment option with quantized models for near-runway cameras.
Cloud analytics handles model updates and reporting (details omitted for public summary).
APIs integrate with airport operations dashboards and maintenance ticketing.

sections.title: Future work
items: Dataset annotation guide and labeling conventions.
Model training recipes for YOLOv8 / Faster R-CNN on runway imagery.
Sensor fusion roadmap for multi-camera persistence tracking.

title: Mini-LLM: Semantic Scholar Assistant
tagline: Chat interface for Semantic Scholar research discovery
summary: Lightweight assistant that pairs conversational search with auto-generated API snippets for Semantic Scholar developers.
imageAlt: Robot assistant figurine beside machine learning books

status.label: On hold
status.note: Concept paused while focusing on current projects.

sections.title: Goals
items: Provide a chat interface for Semantic Scholar search and summarization.
Generate example API calls and code snippets for common workflows.
Offer quick citation formatting and literature overviews.

sections.title: Implementation ideas
items: Frontend: lightweight streaming chat experience.
Backend: proxy to Semantic Scholar API plus LLM for rephrasing results.
Security: rate-limiting, caching, and provenance tracking for generated code snippets.

sections.title: Example snippets
sections.content:
Small runnable examples to get started.

Python (requests) — fetch paper metadata
import requests
resp = requests.get("https://api.semanticscholar.org/graph/v1/paper/ARXIV:2301.10140?fields=title,abstract,authors,year")
print(resp.json())
curl — search
curl "https://api.semanticscholar.org/graph/v1/paper/search?query=semantic+search&limit=5"
Client-side pattern (proxy)
// Client calls your backend: GET /api/s2/paper/ARXIV:2301.10140
// Backend forwards to Semantic Scholar with your API key and returns the response.
fetch('/api/s2/paper/ARXIV:2301.10140').then(r=>r.json()).then(console.log);

sections.title: Future
items: Add citation export (BibTeX, RIS) with Publications page integration.
Allow plugin-style connectors for other scholarly APIs.
Explore assisted prompt building for RAG pipelines.

sections.title: Backend notes
body: Production deployments should keep API keys server-side and proxy requests. Apply caching and rate limits to protect the upstream API.
